text:
- Welcome to the Executive
Insights Podcast,
brought to you by AWS.
My name is Tom Soderstrom,
and I'm an enterprise strategist in AWS.

And today we have David
Villaseca with us from Moeve
a global energy company.

David, would you mind talking
a little bit about yourself

and Moeve and what you do
and what the vision is?
- Thank you, Tom.
I'm chief digital officer of Moeve.

My role is making sure
that we are accelerating

the energy transition
with digital solutions.

My background, I was previously
working in Silicon Valley
for a hyperscaler corporation,
and now we have really a great challenge.

Moeve is a new brand and
previously have a history

of 90 years of experience
in the energy world.
And now we are through a great
and strong transformation

in order to accelerate
the energy transition.

- You got rid of 70% of
your oil focus, didn't you?
- Yeah, that's true.
- Why and how did that go?
We talk about digital transformation.
This was a big one.
- We have two different challenges.

On the one side, we have a
profound business transformation
alongside the energy transition.

And we have a lot of challenge
in this transformation,
and we need to empower our colleagues

and our customers, B2B
customers and B2C customers,
in their own decarbonization journey.

In this way, we call
this vision “Green Digital”

because we are using data,
artificial intelligence,
and IoT to empower our colleagues
and customers in their own transformation.

- Interesting, we're going
to dig deeper on this one.

So as an enterprise strategist,
I talked to hundreds
of executives across the world,

and this year, their
priorities have changed.

The thing that I hear most
about now is the need for speed,
the need to move faster, to transition
to profitability, to change.

So you're doing a big transition
with a need for speed.
What do you see happening?

- I think that we have a lot
of key performance indicators
in a few years to fulfill
with this transformation.

So this idea of need for speed
in our case is at the core
of our own transformation.
And to share some KPIs, for example,
by 2030, in a few years,

we need to reduce our
carbon footprint by 55%,
which is a huge impact.

On the other hand, we need to
make sure that more than half
of our EBITDA comes from the new renewable
and sustainable sources of energy,
which is a huge transformation.

That's why we need to
empower our colleagues
and customers with that data

and with artificial
intelligence solutions.

I think that at the end of
the day, we need to make sure

that we are accelerating
this transformation.
And that data cloud and generative AI.
And just some elements,
because we need to do a change management
with our corporations.
- David, I really like that.

I like your vision and I
like the fact that, I mean,

sustainability is
everybody's key priority.

It's all of our problem to
solve our burning planet.
What you mentioned is two things.

One is you have a corporate
goal that's tough,

just like Amazon is going to
be carbon neutral by 2040,

water positive by 2030, but
you need those big goals.
So that’s one.
The other one is sustainability is not
just a good thing.

It's good for the business,
it's good for the pocketbook.
So I applaud you for doing this,
and I think it's going to be fantastic
to look at your journey.
- No, I think that at the end of the day,

we're combining an impact
in terms of business growth,
and for example,

with some artificial
intelligence solutions,
we have an annual return over 300%,
sometimes even 1000%.

So we are making a
positive impact in our P&L,
but at the same time, we are making sure
that we are using artificial intelligence

to accelerate our own
decarbonization journey.
And I think that there are some figures
that are really interesting to share.

- Yeah.
- For example, according
to the World Economic Forum,

artificial intelligence
solutions can accelerate

the decarbonization in the
world around 5 to 10% by 2030.

That's another way to think
in terms of need for speed
in terms of decarbonization journeys.
- Yeah, that's great.

So internet of things,
and machine learning,
and generative AI.
Buzzwords, but very important buzzwords.

You've done some interesting
things in analytics
and machine learning.
Do you want to talk about those?
I think everybody will be interested.

- I think that there are
interesting learnings

on how these buzzwords are
really transforming our business.

And for example, if you
think about our energy parks,

for example, we are helping
to have diversified sources
of clean energy, for example.

And we are empowering with data
gathering from IoT sensors,
our colleagues in the field,
because they have the knowledge
to optimize their operations.

I think that this is something
really important for us,

and for example, we
have different solutions
and we can talk about that later.

For example, we have an
artificial intelligence
governance platform, which is important
in our case in Europe.

And also we have a generative
AI factory that help us

to develop at scale
solutions for our colleagues
and optimize the way they're working.
I think that this is also,
it's important for our own transformation.

- Yeah, I was interested
in the AI act from Europe,
so you already touched on that.
Are you going to be compliant with that?
- Yeah, for sure.

I think that we have
a human first approach

to these huge compliance
requirements in Europe,
and the idea is that we need to make sure
that we are all aligned,
and we have this people first approach.
And for example, we have a joint data

and artificial intelligence
governance model.

For example, we have built
a new data management office

that works together with
our business colleagues

to make sure that they have
their right data owners.
I think that this is an important element.
And then democratization of data
and artificial intelligence.

We're making sure that all our
colleagues know how to handle
these artificial intelligence solutions.

And for example, we have
the digital skills training
to around 2000 of our colleagues,
and then we have built specific skills.

And we have around 250
citizen data scientists

that are business
experts, process experts,
that now they use our data science tool,
artificial intelligence tool.
I think that this is something important.
And then for sure you need to be compliant
with our artificial intelligence act
in the European Union.

These regulations is specific
limits on what can be done

and cannot be done with
artificial intelligence.

And beyond that, we have built
our own ethical principles.
And at the end of the day,

we need to reduce the
complexity of this governance.
And that's why we have built
an artificial intelligence governance
and observability platform.
I think that this is interesting.
Because we have built 100% in-house
and it's focused on governance,

and this idea of managing
the ethical principles

in all of our artificial
intelligence solutions.
On top of that, we need to make sure

that we have the right
human insight approach,

making sure that we are
co-creating with our colleagues,
with our customers, the right solutions.
And at the end of the day,

because of our commitment
to sustainability,

we need to make sure that in
all the different artificial
intelligence developments,
we are optimizing the energy consumptions
and reducing the potential emissions.

I think that that's
something really important on
how can we leverage these regulations
and going beyond just the compliance part.

- My background is I was
Jet Propulsion Laboratory's
chief technology innovation officer.
It's part of NASA.
And you mentioned citizen scientists.
Music to my ears.
Citizen scientists can do so many things.

They can help you, and they're
free labor essentially,

but they want to participate,
they want to do good things.
How do they get access?

How do you give them
access to do good things?

- I think that we have
combined different approaches.

First, this is about
developing their digital skills
and artificial intelligence skills.

So there is a lot of
training on this part.

And then we need to make
sure that we are delivering
the right tools and solutions.

And for example, we have
built a generative AI factory
where we can develop the right assistance

and the right agents to
empower and help them.
And we have built this platform
and this factory on generative AI

to make sure that we help
them reusing the right models.
So we are doing in an efficient way.

And again, and coming back to
the point of sustainability,

we are making sure that
we are selecting the best

LLM solutions and not just
in terms of cost or accuracy,

but also in terms of the
energy consumption, again.
And we are empowering, for example,

with assistance for field
workers in the service stations
or in the energy parks.

And I think that this is
really useful for them
to get to the right procedures.

And we are also helping our
engineering teams or even HR.

So I think that these are a
lot of different opportunities

that we are leveraging these
citizen data scientists
and all the colleagues.
- Now you mentioned something interesting,
which is different LLM models.
Of course, we in AWS don't believe
there is one ring to rule them all.

In fact, each large language
model will improve and innovate

and our customers will pick the
best one for their use case.
In the end, how many language models
do you think you'll use?

- I think that where we
are releasing is that,
in just couple of years,
we have really expanded our capability.
And when Amazon shares
that they have a new solution
and new foundational model as Amazon Nova,
we are able in the real time to compare
with our different solutions
and choose the best one for our needs.

So I think that in the future
we can have different LLMs.
Because right now we have different
LLMS for different needs.
Sometimes you need maybe something cheaper
in terms of a scale.

Also, sometimes you need to
have a more advanced models.
And I think that at the end of the day,

we need to make sure
that we are the owners
of this decision.

Yeah, I think that that's
the best part of, for example,

our collaboration, our
generative AI platform
with AWS Bedrock solution.

I think that that's really
useful for us to choose

and pick the best LLM
model for each application.
- Yeah, and you will learn a lot

and the world will learn from
what your experiments are.
The other thing we're seeing

with generative AI is it brings
back the importance of data.

And of course, you are
having a lot of data.

What can you share about
the amount of data,
the data strategy, the variety of data,

and how it affects what
you're going to do?
- I agree that what learning that we have
is really to make sure that
all your artificial intelligence solutions

are built over a strong
foundation of data.

And in our case, in Moeve,
we have been working

the last six years in
our journey to the cloud.

And we have developed around
400 data driving solutions,
and we are working across 12 data domains.

So for us, we have a lot of
experience on this area of
that data strategy.

And I think that the point
is that this is not enough.

- Yeah.
- And right now,

as much as we are using
artificial intelligence

and getting a good return
on their investments,

we are increasing our
efforts on data gathering.

We need more data on our
different touch points
in our different assets.
And the right data quality is important.
In our case, I was talking previously
the data management office take care
of the quality of this information.
And having the right metadata.

And I think that these are
some elements that we need

to take into account
always is a combination
of data management

and then artificial
intelligent development.
- Good, I like the sound of that.
It's interesting.

Now I heard of Moeve's 2030
Positive Motion strategy.

- Yeah.
- Share a little bit
about that great sounding initiative.
- Yeah, I think that the Positive Motion
is a vision of the Moeve transformation.
We are all working with the same purpose.

And I think that we have
these strong indicators

that we need to make sure that
we are churning the business.
We have, you were talking about,
we have sold most of our investments
in the upstream business,
and we are investing to make sure
that we are betting on this biofuel
and green hydrogen solutions.
I think that's something meaningful.

We are for sure combining
the electrical vehicles
with different solutions across the world.

And for example, green
hydrogen is really important
for our transport
and industrial customers in the B2B world.
So I think that at the end of the day,

we are betting to be the
leaders in the southern part
of Europe in these sustainable energies.
And that's really a purpose for all of us.
The digital teams and all our colleagues.
We are working with the same vision.
I think that that's really powerful.
The purpose that we share.
- Yeah, the mission is super important.
I’ll share a story from NASA.

When John F. Kennedy, the
President, came to NASA,

and said, "In 1962, we're
going to put a man on the moon.
Not because it's easy, because it's hard."

He asked a janitor, he said,
"What do you do for NASA?"
And the janitor could have said,

"I helped make it clean
for the engineers."
He did not.

He said, "I'm helping to
put a man on the moon."

And so the mission
statement was very clear.
And with your mission,

what would you say is the
mission statement of Moeve?
- We have a clear vision,

and we want to make sure that
we are empowering the world.
Different industries, different people,
with sustainable energy.

- Good.
- To make it possible,

this growth, but at the same
time to make it sustainable.

I think that that's really
a powerful vision for us.

And this idea of Positive
Motion reinforces the idea
that we need to have a positive impact
and everything that we are doing.

These times, I think
that it's really powerful
and it really help us to attract talent
in our digital skills.
For example, you imagine, data scientist,
it’s tough to get this specialist.

And the great thing is that
we can attract this talent
because we have this vision.

And we can attract also
conscious customers

that are willing to transform
either B2C, their own mobility
in a sustainable way,

but also the B2B leaders
that they need to transform
their own industries.
And in Europe with these new regulations,
that empowers the energy transition.

We have a lot of conversations
with airline leaders.
And they ask us about,

"How can we use the sustainable
airline fuel," for example,

"That we are producing in
your new biofuel plants,

to accelerate our business
in a sustainable way?"
I think that this type of conversation,
they're really interesting.
And we are co-creating with them solutions

based within data and
artificial intelligence.

Also, not just to empower our
own decarbonization journey,
but also to help them, to empower them.

- Yeah.
- In their own
decarbonization journey.
I think that that's really powerful.

And we can expand our
"Positive Motion" vision
as a shared vision in the society.
I think that this is really powerful.

- One question that just
popped into my head is,
as we talk to customers across the world

that have to go through
this digital transformation,
the culture is hard to change.
How are you finding that?
Has it been difficult?
- I think that in our case,

the first part is the new
vision that we have served.
This new mission in 2022 has been really
the first lever
of the transformation of the culture.

So I think that culture
is really a tough work.

- Yeah.
- So we have a clear vision.
Digital has been also another lever
to accelerate this culture.

New design thinking, agile,
and different methodologies

can help us also to
transform our own culture.
At the end of the day, we are a company
with more than 90 years of history.
But at the same time,
we have just a couple of years of history
with this new vision.
And it's really a powerful way
to really empower all of us together.
- So the strong mission will help
to make this culture transformation.
Beause a 90-year-old company,
it's hard to change as we're seeing.

But congratulations,
you're well on your way.
- [David] We are working on that.

- And you are the chief
digital officer, right?
So this is your challenge.

- Yeah, I think that when I
was living in Silicon Valley

and I received the call
of this corporation,
I thought that it was really important,
because we are making history.

- [Tom] Yeah.
- And then we call it

the "twin transition", but
it's a triple transition.

Twin transition means
that we need to accelerate
energy transition with digitalization,
but at the end of the day,
we are also transforming business.

I think that this is something
that a lot of colleagues
in different industries,
they're going through this same need.
They need to transform,
and data and artificial intelligence,
it's really a source of empowerment
for this transformation.
I think that even the assistants,
and the agents are empowering us
to share some common thoughts.

I think that there are
really powerful tools
that we are sharing with our colleagues
- As I think about the triple transition,
I like that, that's new.
I have not heard that from anybody else.

If you were saying you were
going to give recommendations

to people, first executives,
actually executives and users,
what are three things you recommend?

- My first advice would be
use artificial intelligence
to empower your energy transition
and decarbonization journey.

I think that this is
something really powerful
that all of us, we can do.
So I think that the question is
that we are empowering also our customers
with our mobile solutions driven by data
and artificial intelligence.

- [Tom] Interesting.
- To make sure

that they are also having
a better experience
if you are charging your car,

or if you are going through
these new biofuel solutions.
And I think that this is really powerful,
that we are also empowering our friends
and families in their daily lives.
I think that this idea that

that energy transformation is
not just for B2B customers,

there are also for all of
our friends and families,
for all of us.

And I think that again, data
and artificial intelligence,

we are empowering this new
multi-energy experience.

I think that this is
something really important

for all of us to have a
positive impact together.

Second, I would say this
idea of human first approach.

This is not just about
technology or data or LLMs.
It's about making sure that we are
leveraging this technology

and taking into account the
pain points of the people,
of our colleagues, of our customers.
And we need to co-create the solution.

And then comes the LLM,
then comes the data.

- Yeah.
- And the nicest part
in terms of the technology.

But I think that we need to
take into account that we need
to work together, people and technology.

We need to work together
and connect the dots.

And third element for
me should be making sure
that you have the right approach in terms
of value and measurement.

I think that we are
getting really huge impact
in terms of growth, business growth,
and business transformation.

Because we are measuring the
return of the investment.

- Yes.
- Was sharing this idea
of over 300%.

And this really resonates
with our shareholders,

it’s about making sure that we
are helping the P&L growth.

This value based approach
is really powerful.

And combining business growth
and decarbonization journeys.
I think that this is really powerful.
- I think that's a really good point.
If I were going to going to give my three,
it would be that one.
Being sustainable is good for business.
The other one be for the executives.
Set an aggressive goal, as you have done.

And the third one is just
experiment your way forward.

Fast and scrappy and easy to
reach those eventual goals.
So last question.

When you look back at this,
so you mentioned 2030.
2030 is a big goal for you.

So year 2030, what do you
want to be remembered for?

- I would say that we really
make a positive impact
in the society.

Because we really empower
the new combination

of digital solutions and
new sustainable energy.
I think that this is really powerful,

and I really think that in a
few years, several companies,

energy companies, will
be on this same path.

- [Tom] Yep.
- So I really hope
that we are seen as a trendsetter

in this energy transition,
empowered by data,
artificial intelligence, and IoT.
So I do really think that building

new digital native plants,
as we are doing of biofuel

and green hydrogen, we
can be really trendsetters
for other companies that can leverage
on our own journey to make it even faster.
- That a great vision.

That's something that you
can tell your children
and eventual grandchildren that,

"Hey, I was part of this,
starting this journey."
- We are making a history together.
- We are making history.
So I want to thank you for your insights,
this executive insight and good luck.
We need you, thank you.
- Thank you.
